title: hard to leave
text: Pros The people who work here are some of the brightest, grittiest minds in the business, and they create a culture of hard work that's infectious. Cons Internal and GroupM barriers seem to make it hard for Mindshare to provide competitive compensation. It's a tough time in a competitive industry, but talent is often forced to look outside of the company for any significant improvement to their salary.

title: Too big and no focus
text: Pros Mindshare brand is perceived as strong and they are part of a strong network. Small pockets of greatness. Fully depends on the team you work on. Cons Overly hostile individuals in senior roles. There are many sub-brands within Mindshare that are constantly in pitch mode but do no real work. The teams that do have client work are under-staffed and over-worked. Mindshare is unable to be agile and there is no formal training or process which is odd given the size. Advice to Management Do not reward or allow a bully leadership style. Have formal training for every level of employee. Operate with a small shop mentality vs. "too big to fail" approach. Promote a work/life balance for your employees Get rid of people who work on nothing and just self-promote through politics. Do away with the sub-groups and have one team
pros: Mindshare brand is perceived as strong and they are part of a strong network.
cons: Overly hostile individuals in senior roles.
advice: Do not reward or allow a bully leadership style.
